content: TERMINATION AFTER 1997 OF TAX SUBSIDIES FOR LARGE PRODUCERS OF ETHANOL USED AS A FUEL. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to deny credit for alcohol used to produce ether and reduce incentives for ethanol fuel production. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exempt liquids used in off-highway business use from certain taxes. Off-highway business use is defined as per section 6421(e)(2), excluding use in a diesel-powered train. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exempt liquids used in off-highway business use from certain taxes, excluding use in a diesel-powered train. Amendments include repealing the reduced rate on ethanol fuel produced from natural gas and making conforming amendments to excise taxes, treating fuel alcohol the same as other motor fuels. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exempt fuel alcohol from certain taxes, defining it as alcohol produced from sources other than petroleum, natural gas, or coal. The rate of tax is adjusted to include fuel alcohol, and special rules for tax imposition are established. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempts fuel alcohol from certain taxes, defining it as alcohol produced from sources other than petroleum, natural gas, or coal. Special rules for tax imposition on fuel alcohol are established, including treating the distillery as a refinery and repealing reduced rates on alcohol fuels. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempts fuel alcohol from certain taxes and establishes special rules for tax imposition on fuel alcohol. This includes amendments to sections 4091, 40, and 4041 of the Code, specifically striking subsection (c) and making conforming amendments related to the volume of alcohol for tax credit purposes. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding tax imposition on fuel alcohol. This includes changes to sections 4041, 6427, and 6427(k) of the Code, such as removing subsections and paragraphs related to tax credits and refunds. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involve redesignating subparagraphs and inserting new subparagraphs related to tax imposition on fuel alcohol. This includes changes to sections 4041 and 6427 of the Code. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involve redesignating and amending various sections related to fuel alcohol tax imposition. This includes changes to subsections of sections 6427, 9502, and 9503 of the Code. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involve redesignating and amending various sections related to fuel alcohol tax imposition. Paragraph (3) of section 9503(f) is amended to adjust the Highway Trust Fund financing rate for methanol or ethanol fuel. The effective date for these amendments is January 1, 1998. A floor stocks tax of 18.4 cents per gallon is imposed on fuel alcohol held on January 1, 1998. A floor stocks tax of 18.4 cents per gallon is imposed on fuel alcohol held on January 1, 1998. Liability for the tax applies to those holding fuel alcohol on that date, with payment due by June 30, 1998. Definitions for fuel alcohol are provided in the subsection. Fuel alcohol is considered held by a person if title has passed to them. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. The tax on fuel alcohol does not apply if a credit or refund is allowable for exempt uses. No tax is imposed on fuel alcohol held in a vehicle tank. No tax is imposed on fuel alcohol held by a person if the amount does not exceed 2,000 gallons on January 1, 1998, and if the necessary information is submitted to the Secretary. Fuel held by a person exempt from tax under certain conditions is not considered for this exemption. The term "controlled group" for corporations is defined as all persons treated as a single entity, with the threshold of "more than 50 percent" replacing "at least 80 percent" as per tax regulations. Under regulations prescribed by the Secretary, principles similar to those for controlled groups apply to nonincorporated persons under common control. All provisions of law applicable to taxes imposed by section 4081 also apply to floor stock taxes imposed by paragraph (1).
